commentBody: Nice quick Friday to end the work week, for those *not* in the US. Hope y'all had a nice Thanksgiving.

This was no turkey, and it was light enough for those who had too much (turkey or rebus) yesterday.

I'd say VENUS FLYTRAP was a TRIED AND TRUE seed, Jacob.

This had some nice clues and the fill was clean. But overall, this puzzle had the difficulty of a Tuesday puzzle. 

The constructor should have seen this, and the editing team should have done better to make this at least slightly challenging for a Friday.

3.5/10.

Name drop alert‚Ä¶my father-in-law is buried next to the immortal Rick James in Forest Lawn Cemetery, Buffalo NY.

Went smoothly for me. Knocked half off my average for a Friday.

I woke up in the middle of the night so unusually I'm one of the first posters. It's just past 4 AM here. 

I personally found this unusually easy for a Friday, despite being unfamiliar with most of the trivia. I completed the puzzle in Tuesday/Wednesday time, and just 3 minutes slower than this week's Monday (which was surprisingly difficult for me). Now I'm wondering if the grid was undercooked for this late in the week, or maybe my good performance was down to that preternatural clarity of mind one sometimes enjoys having woken up way too early.

There was nothing particularly interesting about this one, was there? Just one thing comes to mind: would a sommelier recommend the house wine, of all things? I don't know about the US but in Europe house wine usually is good value for money and perfectly fine for casual wine drinkers. It's what you get when you're not a wine snob, often after rolling your eyes at the expensive wine list the sommelier presents you with, taking you for the sort of person who will pay three times as much for a glass of red than for your main dish ü§∑üèΩ

Thank goodness for a puzzle that does not require one to stuff nine letters in a single cell -I'm thinking yesterday, yeesh!  
This was an enjoyable solve.

"I've told you a thousand times! Our horizontal coordinates are still not correct!"
"Wow. You really have a bad latitude."

("But I don't know where I am!"
"Well, you need to map out of it.")
Fun Friday puzzle. Had 'CHEESE PULLS' for 6D and was starting to form a rant in my head about how it's not a kind of junk food before I realised my mistake.

I was curious if others would have found this easy or not; I finished it quickly but had to jump around a lot, and I had a few footholds with proper names which I wasn‚Äôt sure others would know immediately. Seems like so far that‚Äôs the case but it‚Äôs early and the jury‚Äôs still out.

Still I enjoyed it, and it was nice that even when I had one or two sections the rest weren‚Äôt gimmes. Gotta thank Steve L today, if memory serves, for using SETTERS in a comment recently which would have been a mystery otherwise. Gotta show some love for ROSIE although it‚Äôs a gutsy call to cite a character who is barely in the books or movie; still that last scene of LOTR is so affecting and IMO is one of the best endings in literature, I for one will never forget her name. Had a few misdirects which didn‚Äôt fit the puzzle so didn‚Äôt slow me down;  thinking of EMMA before ALICE, CRACKERJACKS before CHEESECURLS and some sort of office putting green before WORKETHIC. And everyone, you are entitled to your opinions but remember BADATTITUDEs are not constructive. George‚Äîthis may be an easier Friday, or not, but Tuesday??!! Come on.

Lots of fresh entries and some good clues in this one, especially the clues for VENUSFLYTRAP and WORKETHIC.  I tried REED for the James in the R&B hall of fame, thinking of the great Jimmy Reed, and only got RICK from the crosses.  I was puzzled as to who James Rick was until the lightbulb illuminated, oh RICK James.  Got me. Face Palm.

I was thrilled to see ARTTATUM make an appearance here.  He‚Äôs one of my favorite jazz pianists whose intricate riffs on the great American songbook for solo piano, are nothing short of amazing.  Some find his style too ornate, but his technique, replete with glissandos and embellishments, is beyond compare.  So high was his reputation among his peers that Fats Waller (no slouch himself) was reputed to have said upon seeing Tatum enter a club where Fats was playing, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just a piano player, but God is in the house.‚Äù  If you give him a listen, play the tune several times, the depth and complexity of what he‚Äôs doing become clearer on repeat listening, but he never forsakes the original melody.  The clue references Tea For Two, but my favorites are Aunt Hagar‚Äôs Blues and The Way You Look Tonight.

I'm with Andrzej on this one, no sommelier is going to recommend the house red which is by definition plonk. Tonight at TG dinner we had a great Chateauneuf-du-Pape from 2009 and a fine Meursault a friend brought along.  Tomorrow it's back to the plonk no sommelier would tout, some Apothic $5.99 stuff I happen to like. I also like cheese curls.

How many of you had Etta before Rick? And whose consideration of Rick James has at least been partly shaped by Dave Chappelle's recurrent parody of him on the Chappelle Show? (Link below). Answer -- me and me.

Poor Uta Hagen, the only Uta famous enough to be in a crossword, and I guess for Fridays a "setter" must avoid her, since that would be overly tried and true, so then it's on to the sports ticker clues, nothing to be done about it. Poor setter. 

I endorse the soundtrack of this puzzle: Art Tatum, Rick James, Bono, the Maytals. I'd bet good money there's a band out there called Bad Attitude and I'd also bet that they are not A-One and that no sommelier would recommend them, either. House bands and house reds...
48D could perhaps have used a bit more nuance, as the ownership is now Japanese.

I do the crossword every day for decades. I always complete it. I will when necessary go to the crossword column page. I swear starting something like 45 days ago or so that the number of hints markedly decreased. I felt that the crossword columnists were just putting the time in. It did not defeat me, but I feel for newbies. This trend was not a good thing.

Oops! Or should I say "quelle honte?"  The clue and fill for 5D don't match. St. Denis is not a "neighborhood in Paris," as the clue would have it.  St. Denis is a city (commune) unto itself, the innermost northern suburb of Paris. It is neither a neighborhood nor in Paris.

A solid puzzle, with some fun clues and misdirects, but pretty easy for a Friday. Not difficult, but engaging, which seems just right for a holiday.

Thank you, Jacob.  I'd say you're a fine SETTER.
I got a PR today and this past Wednesday! I was actually getting slower for a long time so this feels good. Have a great weekend everyone!!
McDermott for a great Black Friday Puzzle.  We all get a door prize with this treat of a puzzle!!
Cute. Fun. Quick.
Fun puzzle. Slow start for me. Everything was in my head, but getting it out was another thing.

A bit tough for me in spots because I don't follow entertainment news, but there was enough stuff I did know to get me through most of it without too much difficulty.

Thanks, Jacob!
I've tried to Guess but no luck. How is LEE  a Guess alternative?

anyone else catch DEES and RICK as a side-by-side reverse RICK DEES?
shame it wasnt worked into the solve somehow.

My favorite clues were 14A (for WORK ETHIC) and 37A (for VENUS FLY TRAP); my least favorite was 50D (‚ÄúLocked horns‚Äù for AT IT). 

I finished the puzzle listening to ART TATUM, who I first heard of while solving 35A :) Thank you to the constructor for the introduction.

Thank you for an LLM free puzzle. 

Calling it AI is an insult to intelligence.  At my work when it‚Äôs used it‚Äôs referred to as the ü¶ã. The butterfly wrote this or said this allows for the chaos that sometimes follows and avoids giving it any veneer of respectability. 

With the exception of the natnick A at 35A/36D the rest was a good fair workout. 

Thanks

Yesterday's theme inspired me to do some math if my own. When I arrive in class at uni, I am always puzzled by the notes from some math-related course. Well, today I decided to improve the flip chart. Can you spot Andrzej's addition? ü§™ (There are two, but one involves Polish, so the community gets a pass on that one) https://imgur.com/a/m2iZPal
I thought softball question as lob was kind of weak. They‚Äôre both using the same idea since a softball (pitch) is a lob. You need another metaphor, like gimme or slam dunk.
I disagree with the answer to the Musical genre of Toots and the Maytals.  They are reggae.  100%
St. Denis is not a neighborhood in Paris. It's a suburb of Paris.
Enjoyed this one, decent crunch but flowed well and no obvious clunkers for clues. More of these please!
Enjoyed immensely. Nice job!
I had ENhORSE for a bit. You know, when you enhorse yourself after falling off and you're [Back in the race?]
My first instinct for the James clue was Etta, which gave me a headache for a while.

Oh, I loved this one. A Friday where I only needed help with a couple of names - I‚Äôll take it! I loved the long answers. Some clever cluing. This was just fun. Thanks, Jacob! Happy Friday, y‚Äôall. If you‚Äôre out shopping, be kind!

ART TATUM was The Man. OMG such skill, such crisp playing, such beauty. Here. You owe yourself at least this -- two-and-a-half minutes of pure virtuosity: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=35tR9Slmql8&list=RDEM8fz5yQ2L7r9pQAkiolEYgQ&index=4
I had to learn the hard way it wasn‚Äôt Icare or Itsok.
I filled in 15D from the crosses and stared at the answer for a while, convinced it meant that one who was at the back of the race was the END ‚ÄòORSE.

We‚Äôre making plans for a trip to Paris in a few months.

We are learning every day
as we research each arrondissement,
and have a map taped to the pantry door,
right in front of me, as I solve,
with a red dot on the place we are staying,

on Rue de St Denis.

The puzzle can be creeeeeepy‚Ä¶

This was a good puzzle. Not too hard, but I didn‚Äôt find it easy like the aoners.

I know that‚Äôs not Charlie Hustle in the photo. Any current baseball fans who can identify the blurry player?

Beat my Friday average, but I didn't find it easy.

I confidently filled in ISLANDERS for 17A, and then I quickly deleted it. Wait, Bahrain is an island? Yes, as it turns out.

Also, since so many of us are thinking of it on the day after Thanksgiving, if another constructor wants to use VENUSFLYTRAP as a seed, WKRPINCINCINNATI works as a spanner and DRJOHNNYFEVER, LESNESSMAN, and HERBTARLECK all fit.

"As god is my witness, I thought turkeys could fly."
I love it. Just the right level of spice and crisp.

Loved this one. Had almost nothing through the top 11 rows on my first pass, but gained some traction in the bottom four rows and slowly worked my way up, finally finishing in the northwest and top center, with the answer for the delightful ‚ÄúDrive around the office?‚Äù being the last of many aha moments. Thanks, Jacob!

A pair of answer lists to start:

Debut answers aren‚Äôt automatically good, but, IMO, six of the seven today were worthy Times oeuvre additions:  BAD ATTITUDE, BOOK A ROOM, DANCE TROUPE, HOUSE WINE, STAY OUT OF IT, and VENUS FLYTRAP.  Mwah!

A first-name windfall, with NAOMI, RICK, RORY, FAYE, ROSIE, RENE, ALICE, and not-clued-as-names DOTTY, OLLIE, UTA, and LEE.

Then a pair of banger original clues: [Drive around the office] for WORK ETHIC and [Prepared statement?] for I‚ÄôM READY.  That terrific clue, [Plant eater?] for VENUS FLY TRAP, showed up in June in the New Yorker, but it‚Äôs clear from his notes that Jacob came up with it independently.

And thrillingly, a pair of glory moments for me, getting TRIED AND TRUE off the U, and getting VENUS FLY TRAP off the A. 

What a beautifully built grid, Jacob, a low-count 68-worder, hardly a whiff of junk, and 14 longs. This takes another pair ‚Äì talent and grit ‚Äì to pull off.  What a splendid outing you gave me today ‚Äì thank you!

Having read all the comments, I have to laugh at the "house wine" debate here, not long after reading this absolutely hysterical piece in the Washington Post, about the theft of six bottles of French pinot noir from a fancy restaurant in Virginia valued at $38,000. This is a gift article, so it should bypass the paywall. Enjoy. We can all use some levity from something out of Washington. https://wapo.st/3XTgXPV

Typical tough Friday for me. A number of answers that I was never going to get just from the clues, but... working the crosses was enough for something to finally dawn on me. Ended up being a mostly enjoyable workout. Oh... and seven debut answers but UNDERACTS was the only one that was completely unfamiliar to me. A couple of puzzle finds today. The first one a Thursday from January 15, 2015 by Herre Schouwerwou. One square with a "-" (dash) in it rather than a letter. Anyway - the theme answers in order: ICOULDHAVE LOVEDNEWYORK HADINOTLOVED BALTI-MORE Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/15/2015&g=38&d=D I'll put another puzzle in a reply. ...
Prefer the clue Dave Chappelle would have written for 21A, even though I guess I learned a fact from this one.

What a fun journey! I think the best puzzles make you feel like you have completed an epic adventure, overcoming tricky obstacles and getting lost along the way. Then you find the right path and enjoy a hero's success at the end!
Too, too, too many proper names!

This is wild. New Friday PR, breezed through every answer in 8 1/2 min. It felt like a Tuesday (minus the theme) in terms of difficulty. This is not a brag - I am just always so fascinated at how some puzzles just match up to the logic and stockpile of cultural references in our brains in such different ways. Happy solving this weekend.

I loved this puzzle ‚Äî there were several entries that made me grin, or even chuckle semi-audibly. In particular: ENDORSE, WORK ETHIC and IM READY. And also RICK, just because I mindlessly led off with ‚ÄúEtta‚Äù there and was happy to later discover that was wrong.

As for the difficulty discussion: this felt about the same as last Friday *for me*. Putting aside the EYRE/AYO crossing (which took me as long as the rest of last week‚Äôs grid combined), my solve time for each was about a minute over my current Friday average.

Looking back, I can see how today‚Äôs puzzle would have felt much easier if I had either known more of the trivia (RORY and NAOMI were the only two I knew for sure without any crosses, along with narrowing Jazz down to UTA or SLC) or had not been quick to start with ETTA for 21A (which made me second-guess the gimme in 21D, along with holding up the entire NE corner for a bit).

At any rate, I had lots of fun with this one. Thanks, Jacob!

Yowser dowser, as DHubby is prone to exclaim.  
Rhythm and Blues, Disney films, grcery brands that are likely regional, a literary protagonist that was NOT a character imagined by Jane Austen ...how tricky can you get??

PAINT BALL... it can do more than splatter! (Recalling the night our neighbors' storm door glass was shattered, and windows on our station wagon were shot out....orange PAINT but no fingerprints...

"Back in the race" had to be REVERSE, right?
More LOTR characters arrgh!
Is there anyone who DIDN'T play "Tea for Two"??

Maybe I should take up eating candy and other junk food, just to help with solving... 
 A real Saturday workout!  Thanks, Jake.

Enjoyable but not that easy! 
The Star of Life, I didn't know, or ARMISEN, CHEESE CURLS (I read about 'covered in cheese-flavoured powders' so I may remain ignorant). OLLIE was also a mystery, as well as ROSIE and FAYE. 
I don't understand UTA or The Jazz, or AIRS for runs. 

But I got there in the end.

I found this puzzle to be quite challenging, even though xwstats deemed it "easy". I really had to go around the entire grid and chip away. The only gimme proper name was Fred Armisen...maybe I can manage a few Portlandia episodes today for my post-Thanksgiving culinary decompression.
Chewy. And fun !

My thinking while working through this puzzle: WTH is going on here? Tabbed through all the across clues and filled in maybe 6 or so, with a few provisional/probably incorrect answers. Finished in 17 minutes, an epic collapse for a MONDAY puzzle. Started reading the comments and was genuinely confused by all the "Friday" discussion. Took me a while. Holidays really mess with one's sense of time.

Anyway, now that I'm back in reality, those 17 minutes don't look too bad.

Oh... and a couple more puzzle finds. Two more quite unusual ones. First - a Sunday from September 27, 1992 by Robert H. Wolfe with the title "WRYLINES" Some theme answers: MYFAMEISBONDJAMESBOND TOMORROWISANOTHERPLAY HERESLOOKINGATYOUKITT THERESNOPLACELIKENOME MAYTHESOURCEBEWITHYOU Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=9/27/1992&g=68&d=A And.. a Sunday from March 18, 2018 by Daniel Raymon with the title "Taking your Q" Theme answers: QUERYWASHINGTON TRENCHQUOTE HERESLOOKINGATYOUQUID QUICKBOXER PEACHYQUEEN ORDERINTHEQUART Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/18/2018&g=72&d=A I'll shut up now. ...
Liked the puzzle, but one small nitpick. No restaurant that maintains a sommelier is going to be happy if they recommend a HOUSE WINE.

Where is Bill from Detroit??
I have a pie emergency to discuss with him --for future pies' sake, not last night's--  but I guess he's sleeping off T'giving, poor guy.

Wishing everyone a Happy Leftover Day...

I‚Äôd like to have seen Wordplay give a shout out to jazz great ART TATUM. Here‚Äôs a YouTube that shows the nearly blind pianist‚Äôs absolute virtuosity: https://youtu.be/q0QD558TWSQ?si=12BCt0S4rgPRAegC

It was not quite the walk-in-the-park many found it, though I did solve it around 25% faster than my Friday average. I had a bit of a hard time finding a toehold, however, and I ended up filling it south to north. Once I finished I was able to appreciate quite a few clues: 37A ‚ÄúPlant eater‚Äù for VENUS FLYTRAP. 14A ‚ÄúDrive around the office‚Äù for WORK ETHIC. I also appreciated the crossing of YEESH at 43D with SESH at 55A.

Generally after the tougher weekend puzzles I face Monday expecting a letdown and like many post-holiday I woke thinking it was Monday so was delighted to find it was a Friday.

Very nice one today, which makes two in a row that weren't overburdened with trivia.  Never heard of Fred Armisen, but the surrounding clues got it.  Quick question though - what do people in the US call people who create crosswords? I thought everyone called them setters.

Some great cluing in a not-as-hard-as-it-seemed puzzle.

I feel compelled to point out that all plants eat. Venus flytraps are merely some of the few who aren't cagey or crafty enough to do their hunting under cover of night.

Consider the lilies!!
My first answer for 14A, "Drive around the office?" was UNITEDWAY, and while it didn't fit quite as well as WORKETHIC I maintain that it was a fine answer.  YEESH.

I'm glad to see some classic Jazz in today's puzzle.
And I'm grateful, on the day after Thanksgiving, that no one has (yet?) called ART TATUM an obscure musician.
This went better than most Fridays until the north west just stopped me in my tracks.
I just wanted to point out that SHOPLIFTERS also fit in 10D, because today is Black Friday. YEESH!

I just want to give thanks to Christina Iverson for her 'easy mode' clues.  I needed twenty of her clues this morning.  This saved me from 'full cheats'!

Enjoy your weekend, everyone.  (Enjoy your leftovers!)

Oh - one more. A Sunday from January 12, 2014 with the title -'It's only "A" game." Some theme answers: CASABLANCA FALALALALA CATCHASCATCHCAN ALANALDA STARWARS RASTAMAN and... AMANAPLANACANALPANAMA* *21 letters, but that was it's only appearance in any puzzle. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/12/2014&g=28&d=D ...

15D couldn't be "reenter" because of the question mark in the clue. "Underacts" was perfectly fine. This article is a dud and didn't add to my appreciation for the puzzle. Top left corner was the last to come together for me.
Answer key is 404 error

On today's roster of proper names, we're just one shy of a rugby league. 

NAOMI WATTS, RICK JAMES, RORY MCILROY, FAYE MARSAY, ART TATUM, PAUL HEWSON (BONO), ROSIE, ST DENIS, RENE, FRED ARMISEN, ALICE, JOSE OLE.

‚ÄúI wish I had more hands so I can give (this puzzle) FOUR THUMBS DOWN!‚Äù 

Kidding of course, quoting the Chappelle skit. This one gets four thumbs up despite calling Fred Armisen funny. ü§£
I never get the Friday puzzle. Today I got the Friday puzzle (pretty much without a sweat). Was the puzzle too easy or does my 75-year-old brain still have some life in it?
A tried and true Friday challenge. Thanks Jacob!

Very fast today, about half my usual Friday time, which is actually fine because I need to pull out of my holiday laze and get some work done. 

Some clever clues. I especially liked "Drive around the office" and "Prepared statement?" 

The flash mob clue and answer reminded me of something I heard about but never saw. Apparently when the pedestrian scramble was first introduced to our local intersections, during the 15 seconds when pedestrians have use of the entire intersection, improvisational dancers would dash out from the four corners, do a 7 second dance, then dash back.
For 39A I tried far too long to make NUTTERS work, assuming the best possible sense of the word, of course.

A nicely chewy grid, glad to see I‚Äôm spared the nightmare that was yesterday‚Äôs offering.
Felt hard but solved reasonably quickly. Unknown ?comedian? Jazz pianist and the obligatory sports name aside, it was fairly smooth once I got a few of the blanks filled in.

PAINTBALL *shudder* The weekend before I started a new job I was invited to their social outing; paintballing on one of the wettest, coldest days of the year. All went well until some idiot hit me point blank. In the face. Those things Hurt! My first day in the office I looked like I‚Äôd gone 10 rounds with Ali. Several years later I had an X-ray pre dental work. I was asked what treatment I‚Äôd had for my fractured jaw. No wonder it hurt.
Fast, fun Friday for me. I enjoyed the music theme: ART TATUM next to TRIO, ARMISEN, SKA, BELTS, RICK, piano LESSONS, AFRO-Latino, MCS, BONO... I found this to be an A1 puzzle. U2?

My puzzle today is an example of why one shouldn't use "faster than my average" as an indication of whether the puzzle was "too easy." I finished about an hour slower than my average time because I got distracted by a (lovely) conversation with one of my Thanksgiving guests. That number will skew my average Friday solve times longer even though I'd say today was probably a little easier than most Fridays. That said, I loved "Back in the race" even though it was my last answer to fall. :)

A very fine Friday puzzle today! My solve began very slowly, groping for a fingerhold or toehold. FInally it gained some traction, but with the upper left and upper right showing lots of white space. At the end I had WORKET for the "Drive around the office" but could not complete the answer. Laid it aside for five minutes and miraculously was able to see the HIC, and the rest was hicstory. I totally *love* jazz piano renditions of "Tea for Two" and here is an Art Tatum performance (probably not the only such link posted here): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=czZHuYWe2xI . Other stellar performances of a piano jazz "Tea for Two" exist by Adam Makovich (which I cannot find online) and by Stephane Grappelli (best known for jazz fiddle, but also a top-notch pianist).

Took me a while longer than it should have to complete the Friday puzzle because I had CHEESECURDS for a while.  (Assume some of you have been to Quebec and tried their classic dish called ‚Äúpoutine‚Äù.  Certainly not junk food.) Pretty good workout trying to find the name of an exercise in that one!

The less said about about me and this puzzle the better, but not the puzzle's fault. Circling back to the Roger Ebert puzzle comments from a few days ago, a number of people revealed themselves to be John Prine fans. Here's an unlocked article about him and a documentary about him, which is playing at the Quad cinema in NYC and that will be available to stream at some point next year. It features performances from a tribute concert a few years ago. https://www.nytimes.com/2025/11/27/arts/music/john-prine-documentary-you-got-gold.html?unlocked_article_code=1.4k8.gqQF.3jpPoswQLd0r&smid=url-share

5D is not a Paris neighborhood but a city proper outside of Paris. It is where Saint Denis died sometime around 250 CE after being beheaded in Montmartre (Mount of Martyrs) and not dying on the spot. 

Legend has him carrying his head and preaching a sermon over the butte and down the other side. When he finally finishes his speech he drops dead. On the spot, St. Genevieve has a chapel erected which becomes the basilica of Saint Denis. 

A minor quibble to a good puzzle but a fascinating story, which goes much deeper than my short version.

I had a number of lookups even before I gave up and turned to Mr. Aronow for help. Names were a big problem. Some of them were in the 11 clues to names that I couldn't answer (well, I was pretty sure of ALICE) and I only recognize two of the answers, ALICE and BONO. But here is a weird thing that keeps happening to me. I'll see something like ___T_T__ from crossings at 35A and decide to google "art tatum" and it turns out to be a real person's name that I don't remember ever hearing or seeing before! A less startling case was at 30A where crosses gave me __R_. "Maybe rori?" I wondered, seeing a use for the first R. Close enough! The silly app thinks I really solved this puzzle and have a five-day streak!
BTW, Shostakovich orchestrated "Tea for Two" in a composition (Opus 16).

My immediate entry of the crossword go to, ETTA, for 21 across gummed up the northeast corner for me. I kept ignoring my wife's insistence that maybe it's wrong until she finally wore me down and I deleted it. It all fell into place after that. A lesson learned.
The name of the plant, pace the column, is "Venus flytrap" (two words, not three).
Tough but fun,once I changed dings to dents.
Hated this one.

I didn't find this as easy as many here, it seems.

There were a couple spots I recall leaving and thinking "I hope something comes to mind because I'm stuck here, and there are no more answers that will help with crosses.  That's what generally gets me on Fridays and Saturdays these days, a block of two or four or six blank spaces, and nothing is showing up mentally after dozens of trips through the clues.

ENDORSE was one of my last insights, and without it I would have had another blue.
This was a nice challenge but also lots of fun, with some great clues. Thanks, Jacob McDermott, for giving me some chuckles and aha moments while cleaning up from our lovely Thanksgiving dinner.
I've posted this before, but with Fred Armisen in the puzzle, I just had to do so again. Armisen underplays the final lines beautifully. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ie6LpKOJVf0
wow one of the first nonmondays I solved without a single Google or check, and extremely fast for a Friday...
Enjoyed the puzzle, but falling asleep in the sun in the middle of it certainly hurt my average Friday time. Too much tryptophan yesterday.

There is definitely a dad joke here. 
Plant eaters‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶..
Venus fly trap!
I‚Äôm gonna use it for sure
Just the right amount of difficulty today. Lots of clues coming at you from out of nowhere. The best thing is that a puzzle like this forces you to think from multiple angles.

Bit of an odd puzzle find, inspired by current circumstances. I'm now in a VA facility and the one picture I brought with me to hang on the wall is 'The Venetian Lamplighters' by Maxfield Parrish. Because of my compulsive letter counting it dawned on me that that name is 15 letters. And.. it was an answer once - in a Monday puzzle from July 27, 2009. And... the other two 15 letter theme answers in that one were: PUBLISHORPERISH and LOUISIANAPARISH And... the constructor of that puzzle was... Allan E. Parrish Don't ever recall coming upon anything quite like that before. Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/27/2009&g=17&d=A ...

I've been busy insulting Armisen and forgot to say that I quite liked this puzzle, even though it was clearly too easy for a Friday.

Several of the clues - back in the race (particularly), drive around the office - were really quite good, with others - plant eater, prepared statement - almost as much.

Others were disappointingly basic - not above, trusty.

One other thing - the breaks on the 4th row seemed different somehow and refreshing for some reason.

All in all a nice puzzle in my opinion.
Who else thought "fake account" was BOT?
Didn‚Äôt like but a typical Friday puzzle. A lot of very obscure answers.
The constructor faked me out on 21A. R&B "James" in a puzzle Pavlovs me to ETTA, but not this time....
N.B. In case the irony was missed, VENUS FLYTRAP is one of seven debut answers in this puzzle (per xwordinfo.com). This is the fourth appearance of TRIED AND TRUE.

@George Here is the perspective of a newer solver:  I can usually do Tuesdays with no help, but I only got halfway through this puzzle without needing to consult the column (And comments) for hints. @Mike

This comment really is off tropic (or topic) but your pun reminded me a great book recommendation, ‚ÄúLongitude‚Äù by Dana Sibelius. It is a fascinating account of how an 18th century clockmaker, John Harrison, was able to solve a navigational problem which had vexed seagoers for centuries‚Äîhow to accurately determine you longitude at sea. Latitude was easy if you could see the sun or the north stars, but longitude was a huge issue. It‚Äôs a short read but an amazing insight into problem solving. Another rabbit hole, I know, which has nothing to do with the puzzle but that‚Äôs what I love about these comments, personally.

If I may deepen the rabbit hole and recommend two more nonfiction books on seafaring and one on measuring things:

The Wide Wide Sea by Hampton Sides

@SP

I'll say a kind word for Frodo.

Thrust into a horrible situation through no fault of his own, he accepted a suicide mission which would almost certainly fail.  

Jesus-wanna-be, Andrzej?  Hardly.  A hobbit who never had a choice in the matter--refusing to do his duty would mean the end of everything he loved, and he was willing to do it even if he never reaped the rewards--which he didn't.  He suffered from his morgul blade wound so much that he could never enjoy the Shire he'd saved.

The drama for Frodo was internal.  He suffered to such an extent that at one point he tried to separate himself from the rest, hoping that he could save his friends by leaving them behind.  He might have succeeded had Sam not been such a steadfast friend.

His patience and pity for Smeagol was the only thing, in the end, that saved Middle Earth.  Even as guileless a soul as Frodo was unable to bear the corruption of the ring, and his patience with Smeagol paid off in the biggest way possible--a hedge against his own fallibility.

@Francis

I'll give you one thing. You're a better writer than Tolkien ü§£

@Andrzej

Honestly, I can't say that Tolkien is my favorite writer.  Far from it.

His style is so flowery and romantic, echos of what I think of as classical British Literature (which I've never been able to read) that I was mostly trying to wring the actual plot and deeds from the prose.

I also would say that while the story is intense and multi-faceted, there is never the slightest doubt in the readers mind that the mission to destroy the ring would fail, because that just doesn't happen with fantasy literature from that time.

I do applaud him, though, for creating a fascinating "universe", complete with an engaging history (through the appendices--I could never read anything other than The Hobbit and the trilogy--and fictional, functional languages, and the maps, how I loved the maps.

@Andrzej
It can be tricky to know how much social context is needed to understand a clue. You mention 'crate' for dogs. But 'crate' also came up separately in the context of jalopy / wreck /crate. Same word but wildly different contexts. If the answer is 'crate', are we talking pets or cars? Is it a Monday or  a Thursday puzzle? If we add some indicator like, say, 'Peke's home en route', is that too obvious or just helping the solver to see the particular aspect of the solve upon which the constructor relied?

@SBK

I get that. However, sometimes, as with that CRATE clue (this Monday was it?) the column assumes you know what the clue and answer are about already. Why pick it as tricky if you don't comment on what's going on? That was the case with the CRATE answer: all the column had to say was pretty much this: "the answer to the [clue] is CRATE, duh". How is that an explanation of a clue that was qualified as being tricky?

@Andrzej
If that's all the columnist said, it's not very enlightening. But if it's just a synonym or slang expression, how much would saying that add to the solver's understanding? It's only if there's some double meaning or tricky cluing that an explanation is going to help, no?

@SBK I agree with Andrzej on wanting to see an explanation or context or color in the column. If a clue rises to the level of being qualified to count as a tricky clue, then it makes sense to give it a little more air time than just this is the clue and this is the answer. We have the answer key for that. 

Most of the time, the column does do this, and that is what makes it fun to read the column in the first place even when I have no trouble filling in any of the answers. I have noticed in the last couple weeks that it has been a little thinner, though.

@Jim Cohoon

While working through the archives, I‚Äôve noticed that older Wordplay columns were more verbose in general and usually spent more ink discussing each ‚Äútricky clue.‚Äù Not sure if it‚Äôs a change in editorial direction or maybe diminishing enthusiasm from the columnists.
@Jim Cohoon You can get explanations for several tricky answers at this site: https://nyxcrossword.com/ Hope this helps!

Three quarters of my ancestry is untraceable, but the quarter of them that I do know about came to the US from rural Lincolnshire in 1907. Winnie the Pooh (the original, not the dancing, singing, ad-pitching Technicolor Disney version), Alice in Wonderland, The Jungle Book, and other aspects of Victorian England were all part of my childhood and my adult outlook, which is a little strange given that I look a little like a wild-haired elderly version of Ho Chi Minh.

As a child I had no idea that my older relatives had immigrated here. I just thought that as you grew old you started speaking in what I now know was a Lincolnshire accent.

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened: A Thursday from September 5, 2013 by Damon Gulczynski. That one had four squares that apparently could be alternated between two letters, and... with either letter the answers made sense with both the down and across clues. Some examples: 1a: "Belief system founded in China" (M)AOISM (T)AOSIM and 1d: (M)OIL (T)OIL And some other answers, both ways: S(P)ATTERED S(C)ATTERED) (P)HI (C)HI S(P)UTTERED S(T)UTTERED (P)HI (C)HI (R)ICERS (D)ICERS (R)UST (D)UST Here's that link. https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/5/2013&g=39&d=D ...

@Rich in Atlanta Oohh! And yet one more. A Wednesday from October 31 (!) 2007 by Ken Stern. This one also had several double-word rebuses with one working for the across answer and the other for the down answer. But... all of those rebus squares were essentially the same: TRICK/TREAT or TREAT/TRICK Some crossing examples: PRE(TREAT)MENT crossing (TRICK)SOFTHETRADE RE(TREAT) crossing STPA(TRICK) JEANEKIRKPA(TRICK) crossing PEACE(TREAT)Y and, a down answer: (TRICK)or(TREAT) with the crossing across answers: (TREAT)ISE HAT(TRICK) And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/31/2007&g=33&d=D ....

@Steve, thanks for the link.  I was listening to Tea for Two when I saw your comment.

Tatum was one of those Mozart-esque geniuses who could hear something once and then play it almost note-for-note.  There's the famous story when he went into a club where Fats Waller was playing.  Waller saw him, stopped and said ‚Äú Ladies & gentlemen, I just play the piano ‚Äî but God is in the house tonight.‚Äù
@Steve -- Hah!  We have very similar taste in ART.  (See my post below...)

@Don H. Motivated by this puzzle and free YouTube, I just listened for the first time to a bunch of Art Tatum.   Astounding.

The clue is an understatement, like would be ‚ÄúComposer with memorable renditions of ‚ÄòAh! vous dirai-je, maman‚Äô‚Äù .

Which would be Mozart.

My ignorance extended to trying to fit in the only musicians named Art I could think of‚Ä¶ Garfunkel?  Too long.  Arthur Lee, of the great LA group ‚ÄúLove‚Äù‚Ä¶ Tea for Two way outside his ouvre.  Art Pepper?  First near miss.  Ah, Art Blaky, whoever he was‚Ä¶ only the name was on my head, and I had no idea how to spell that right.  Filled that in.

Eventually the crosses jostled Art Tatum and long ago memories of the radio VOA jazz hour program, pre-internet when that was an American broadcast I listened to while overseas, out of long term memory.  

Thanks crossword, constructor, and NYT!

@cameron
Until the mid-20th century, all names had some meaning. It might not be in your language, it might be based on antiquated or obsolete vocabulary, it might be obscure. But, sci fi and fantasy aside, no one just strung nonsense letters or syllables together to make names until 50-75 years ago. Now of course, naming a chlld with a name that anyone else /ever/ had is regarded as hidebound conservatism or a failure of imagination .

Robert Davis, I will grant you that Fred is not everyone‚Äôs cup of tea, but I wish I lived in a world where, however tactile, we all could laugh as hard as I do every time I watch him do Nicholas Fehn on Weekend Update. https://youtu.be/WKLHsJyhTYs?si=gwgTWEWP9rJpXl2c

It's time you learned the truth: what happened had nothing really to do with your writing. Your teacher was evil, that's all. 

If Hemingway, with his style of writing, had been your teacher's pupil, the literary world would have a void where his books should be. 

What you shared with us was beautifully written. But even so,  no one in this forum is here to judge writing acumen nor grammar proficiency, much the less writing style. 

This is a safe space for you to share your experience with the puzzle, your opinion about it, and memories it might evoke or knowledge you might have. 

Start with one or two sentences, if that's what you're comfortable with. Or let it rip with full paragraphs, no matter how long it takes you to write what's on your mind.

This forum is not a writing class nor contest, and there are no evil teachers in sight.

As long as comments are respectful of constructors, editors, columnists, and commenters, we all just want to share experiences about the puzzle, culture, and life itself.
